prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Observing host galaxy of 3c298 with the CO 3-2 line
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose to use the 345.79 GHz CO 3-2 line redshifted into bands 4 to study the properties of high redshift (z=1.4) QSO host galaxies. The larger field of view at this frequency will allow us to study the interaction of quasars and its host galaxy with the surrounding environment at a moderate spatial resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our sensitivity measurements are based off the spectral energy diagram (SED) of 3c298 and its HST observations combined with our previous work on SDSSJ0925+06 in the optical. The peak continuum flux is measured directly from the SED which we derived from literature studies of this target. We looked at line flux measurements of similar quasar targets at high redshift that have a starburst host galaxy with similar total IR flux as our target and concluded that in the outskirts of these galaxies where the CO densities drop we expect that the peak line flux will drop to about 1mJy, while the flux near the cores of the galaxies may be as high as 10-15 mJy, we would like to detect the lowest flux with at least a SNR of ~5 summed over the entire emission line which again from literature studies estimated that a value of 200 km/s is fairly reasonable. Hence we propose a sensitivity limit of 0.2mJy. Archival HST observations of 3c298 reveal that there is extended emission interacting with the host galaxy at angular separation of at least 3”, hence a field of view of 6” and an angular resolution of 0.3” will suffice to study the large scale structure. In addition the redshifted CO 3-2 lines falls in regions of good atmospheric transmission (bands 4). Our observations do not necessarily require high spectral resolution as the targeted CO 3-2 line does not have any additional strong emission lines beside it that could cause blending. But these systems are dynamically active and the velocity shifts of the CO emission relative to the redshift of these sources could be quite large. SDSSJ0925+06 has extended components moving at velocities of about 200 km/s, but in principle these velocities could be much higher especially for outflowing gas. Hence we require the largest spectral bandwidth in order to not miss these components. Standard calibration will suffice our science goals. As recommended by the observing tool we do not require ACA observations, and our observations are not time constrained. With the above constraints the total on source time will be 27.13 min on sources, and the total calibration time is 23.08 min with additional 17.82 min spent on overheads bringing the total science goal time for this set up to 1.13 h. This integration time matches previous observations done with ALMA on high redshift QSO host galaxies with successful CO detection, but with less 12m antennas in operation. asdsd

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Observing host galaxy of 3c298 with the CO 6-5 line
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose to use the 691.437 GHz CO 6-5 line redshifted into bands 7 to study the properties of high redshift (z=1.4) QSO host galaxy. This frequency provides a smaller field of view but a larger angular resolution, we propose to use this set up to study the molecular gas inside the host galaxy of the QSO with higher angular resolution to obtain accurate measurements of the molecular gas/dust mass and distribution inside the host galaxy and spatially resolved kinematics to help understand the morphology, as well as look for regions that may have depleted gas/dust and trying to correlate those positions with AGN ionization phenomena seen with our optical observations.

Hence we selected the CO 6-5 emission line for this science goal since it will provide a field of view of 3.22 arcseconds and a spatial resolution of 0.145”. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Understanding the physical mechanisms and connection between supermassive black hole growth and galaxy formation and evolution remains elusive. In particular, observational properties of host galaxies of distant luminous quasars has remained challenging due to the high contrast needed to separate the bright quasar from the faint, resolved galaxy. We are proposing to observe two carefully selected quasars at a unique stage in their evolution where the host galaxy is undergoing a burst of star formation. In the submm regime we gain the necessary level of contrast to see the light from the host since the energy output from the host galaxy is far greater than due to AGN. Due to high angular resolution of ALMA we will be able to spatially resolve the host galaxy and study several key properties, including molecular gas distributions and masses, dynamical properties from resolved kinematics maps, and host galaxy morphologies. Our ALMA observations will be supplemented with adaptive optics assisted near-IR integral field spectroscopy observations, combining the two will give us a better understanding of the relationship between star formation and AGN activity at these early epochs.
